Introduction

The purpose of this document is to provide a standard operating procedure should a patient require COVID-19 swab testing prior to admission to any of the MSE Trusts for an elective admission to the MSE Trust in the absence of the ability to attend a drive- through or clinic appointment.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide step by step guidance on how to obtain COVID-19 swab samples via the Hospital @ Home service.
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities

The Risk and Compliance Committee (MSE) are responsible for ensuring the Trust is providing a high quality service, monitor and review the quality of services and be responsible to significant patient safety risks.
The Director of Integrated Care is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes are disseminated appropriately and compliance is adhered to
The Head of Integrated care is responsible for ensuring for that monitoring and audit of the  service  are  undertaken  and  that  this  document  is  fully  implemented  at departmental level

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Service Unit Managers/General Managers are responsible  for  implementing  this  document  in  the  Clinical  Service  Unit  and  for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Directorate/Divisional Clinical Director and Associate Director/Divisional General Manager in this respect.

The Operational Lead is responsible for ensuring that all staff within the Hospital at Home service comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will ensure that all necessary training is provided and competencies kept current.

data.text: The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.

The nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the virtual ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward complies with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.

Care-Coordinator working within each site, along with others this team will assess the suitability of patients for the service and will determine the type and nature of care package to be provided. This team will also ensure the individual needs of any accepted patient can be met through the appropriate staffing and use of equipment, aids, support and medication.
Standard Operating Procedure for COVID-19 PCR swab testing via
Hospital@Home service

Elective admission patient identified as being unable to attend drive-through testing facility or Outpatient pre-assessment clinic can be referred to the H@H service for COVID-19 swab testing  hours prior to admission to hospital for elective treatment.
Patients requiring emergency swab testing need to refer to the MSE Trust policy swabbing protocol PF-WI-19:

Staff booking elective admission to identify patients not suitable for drive-through or pre-assessment clinic swab testing, due to either a medical or mobility issue with no other alternative option for transport to a centre.
Referral made via telephone/email to the H@H service for each Trust
Patient allocated to schedule for the local H@H team and H@H COVID-19 testing staff to arrange visit with patient.
Sample obtained as per Section 6
Sample deposited to local Pathology department within locally agreed timeframe to ensure sample processed as per Appendix
Sample to be processed via Patholgy department as set out in appendix I
Elective admission/ medical team to report result in patient medical documentation
and inform patient.
Patient identified as requiring COVID-19 swab testing whilst under the care of the H@H service:
Patient displaying Coronavirus symptoms whilst under H@H care identified (See Appendix 2.)
H@H nursing staff request COVID-19 test via Pathology request system
Medical team for patient updated with patients condition.
Swab obtained during next scheduled visit to patient (See section 6)
H@H nursing staff update patient with results.
Obtaining COVID-19 swab sample
Equipment required:
Swab kit from Pathology - Swab, request form, E28 form, 2xspecimen bags, ‘caution' label
PPE – Apron, gloves, surgical mask, goggles.
Suitable  rigid container to transport samples from patient's home to the hospital pathology department.
Screening procedure
6.2.1 Identify patient by asking for name and DoB. Explain the procedure to the patient and gain consent to obtain the swab.
6.2.2 Please adhere strictly to the following instructions:
Complete a request via an electronic system e.g ICE / Medway by searching for Coronavirus (covid 19) SARS CoV2 PCR – or ‘COVID' in the searchbar.
Complete for E28 – Public Health England COVID-19 Primary Testing form.
Label the vial clearly with the patient details, date sample was taken and specimen type (nasal/throat). There must  be 3 patient identifiers:
Open the swab packet from the top ensuring that you do no not touch the end of the swab.
Take the swab sample as per the standard guidelines for COVID-19 PCR swab testing (upper respiratory tract) – see fig
Open the container taking care not to touch the inside of the tube or the lid
Insert the swab into the vial

If the swab has a notch along the stick portion position it to that point within the tube and snap the swab into the container. If there is no notch break the swab at a point that ensure the cap can be safely secured back onto the tube.

data.text: Transport of sample
Please also refer to policy CP/GU/00362 – Transport of Pathology samples.

The care and preservation of the specimen is the responsibility of the nurse taking the sample  within  the  patient's  home  until  they  deliver  the  sample  to  the  Pathology department. They must check that all the information and documentation are correct before the specimen leaves the patients home.
All diagnostic specimens must be placed a primary sample container, which are sufficiently robust and leak proof under normal use and placed inside a sealed
specimen bag 7.4  The request form must be placed in the separate component of the bag.
This is then placed in a grey cardboard box or designated P650 packaging. This must have a UN3373 diamond sticker and the wording Biological Specimen Category B on one side.

data.url: MSESOP-2005 Hospital @ Home, SOP for COVID-19 PCR swab testing in patients home 1.0.017.png

data.text: Fig
The outer box must be at least 10cm x 10cm, the diamond no smaller than 5cm

sides. The lettering within the diamond and the written description no smaller than 6mm high, the thickness of the diamond border line a minimum of 2mm thick. The box or rigid container should also be labelled with the destination.
The sample transport container should be suitably restrained in the boot and not in the passenger compartment of the vehicle.

data.text: The World health organisation states the following:

The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, dry cough, and tiredness. Other symptoms that are less common and may affect some patients include aches and pains, nasal congestion, headache, conjunctivitis, sore throat, diarrhea, loss of taste or smell or a rash on skin or discoloration of fingers or toes. These symptoms are usually mild and begin gradually. Some people become infected but only have very mild symptoms.
Public Health England gives the following advice to healthcare professionals in the inpatient setting:

Appendix 3: Correct Identification of a patient not in a hospital setting
See also Policy RM11 Patient identification policy and procedure
Check you have arrived at the correct address of the patient using information supplied on the SystmOne caseload schedule.
Ensure the request form has originated from ICE or Basildon pathology service.
Check the patients details against the request form
Ask the patient to state:
Use open ended questions when identifying the patient – ask them to say their name & date of birth.
Ensure you only take the request form for the patient you are attending to into their home (to reduce the risk of becoming distracted in the home and selecting the incorrect form)
If you are unable to confirm the patients' identity you should refer back to the ward manager for you team for further advice.
Misidentification
If a patient is misidentified:
The staff must ensure that the patient has come to no harm and has had the correct treatment/ care
If the patient has come to harm, the lead clinician for the patient must be informed, who will then inform the patient/next of kin
Correction of the incorrect information must be done immediately, so that it does not happen again
This will then be documented in the patient's health care records
Staff must follow the Trust Incident Reporting Policy

To support the MSE in the Reset OF covid-19, by providing a Swabbing service for housebound patients who are vulnerable and considered at risk but require a procedure in hospital

Patients will benefit, and avoid delay in treatment, the service will also benefit by being able to increase caseload capacity to support the MSE.
